text: James "Croesus" Stevenson FRGS FRSE LLD (1822 – 28 January 1903) was a 19th- century Scottish industrialist and philanthropist. ==Life== He was born in 1822 at 63 CandleriggsGlasgow Post Office Directory 1822 in Glasgow, the son of Nathaniel Stevenson (1787–1867), and his wife, Elizabeth Carlile from Paisley.http://www.glasgowwestaddress.co.uk/100_Glasgow_Men/Stevenson_Nathaniel.htm His father by 1840 had founded Oswald, Stevenson & Co, cotton yarn agents and was living at Provanside on Stirling Road. His partner was James Oswald, and their first premises was at 98 Hutcheson Street.Glasgow Post Office Directory 1840 He was a partner in Oswald Stevenson & Co, cotton yarn agents of 23 Royal Exchange Square. In 1850 James lived at 4 Woodside Crescent in Glasgow.Glasgow Post Office Directory 1850 He worked as a dye manufacturer for the calico and linen industries in Glasgow. Over and above taking over Oswald Stevenson in 1843 he also set up Stevenson Carlile with his cousin, Thomas Carlile.http://www.glasgowwestaddress.co.uk/100_Glasgow_Men/Stevenson_Nathaniel.htm He is associated with the importation of sulphur to Britain from around 1870 from the volcanic island of Vulcano north of Sicily. At the same time he collected many antiquities from the neighbouring island of Lipari. He visited Vulcano so frequently that he built a house there, in Scots Baronial style, still surviving and known as the "Casa Dell Inglese" (the English house).https://www.socantscot.org/research-project/stevenson-in-vulcano/ This association named him the nickname "Croesus", reflecting both his new-found super-wealth, and his Italian links. By 1870 he was still living at his father's house at 4 Woodside Crescent, but is listed independently as a merchant trading from 23 West Nile Street.Glasgow Post Office directory 1870 In 1877 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. His proposers were William Thomson, Lord Kelvin, Alexander Crum Brown, Robert Tennent and John Hutton Balfour. He died on 28 January 1903. He never married and had no children. He left his large collection of Lipari antiques to the newly completed Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum. ==Family== His paternal uncle was James Stevenson and his cousins included Flora Stevenson, Louisa Stevenson and John James Stevenson. ==References== Category:1822 births Category:1903 deaths Category:People from Glasgow Category:Scottish industrialists Category:Scottish philanthropists Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh Category:19th-century philanthropists
